author: Andrew P. Street
title: The Verdict recap: Mark Latham and Bob Katter fire up on guns in an otherwise dull episode
text:
Queensland MP Bob Katter in furious debate with Mark Latham about gun control. Photo: Screenshot, The Verdict, Nine Network 
It's week three of Channel 9's The Verdict , and while the show seems to have moved away from it's early model of everyone-shouting-at-once, it hasn't yet worked out an alternative. While the first two episodes were entertainingly infuriating, the latest foray suggested it could become something even worse: painfully dull.
Host Karl Stefanovic seems like he's settling into the gig a little better, but resident pot-stirrer Mark Latham came across as oddly neutered. He seems lost in a world of his own for much of the programme; even when he snapped into life to make his obligatory slams at inner city elites his heart didn't seem to be in it.
He wasn't alone, mind. In fact, for the first half of the show it seemed as though everyone was going to be dangerously reasonable. Alongside Latham was independent MP Bob Katter, journalist Angela Mollard, psychologist Sandy Rae, Mama Mia 's Jamila Rizvi, and ex-Gold Coast Suns player Campbell Brown.
Former Labor leader Mark Latham attacked Mr Katter's views on firearms. Photo: Screenshot, The Verdict, Nine Network 
The first few topics didn't really catch fire: the question of whether Malcolm Turnbull should go to an early election received shrugs – although Katter insisted that Turnbull wouldn't be "timid" enough to go to the polls before 2016. Latham snarled that Turnbull is "the flim flam man," but even that dig seemed limp.
Advertisement Similarly the question of whether the paparazzi should be able to photograph the children of celebrities saw everyone in furious agreement that no, they shouldn't. So far, so dull.
And then it was onto the subject of gun control, which seemed like an easy win. After all, Katter has been outspokenly in favour of allowing more weapons in, and his son-in-law is the current importer of the rapid-fire Adler shotgun. So things were going to get spicy, right?
The full panel of episode three of The Verdict. Photo: Screenshot, The Verdict, Nine Network 
The mood was set with Stefanovic interviewing Walter Mikac, who lost his wife and young daughters in the Port Arthur Massacre. Mikac spoke eloquently about his concerns that Australian gun laws were being "watered down by stealth," pointing out that existing laws are more than generous regarding people owning weapons if they feel the need, "but you don't need to fire eight shots in eight seconds to protect yourself."
And that was powerful, rational stuff - but was there really a need to up the stakes by attempting to get the guy to cry on live TV? Stefanovic pulled out as many emotional questions as possible regarding Mikac's daughters, pointing out that they'd be in their early twenties now - "Where do you think they'd be now? What do you think they'd be doing?" - which Mikac answered with impressive dignity instead of asking what the hell Stefanovic was playing at.
And after the interview, everyone was ready to pile onto Katter about the evils of guns. Latham got a rise by demanding to know "How could you sleep at night if these weapons got on the street… and your family are bringing them in to make a few bob?", but the attacks on Katter's family largely (ahem) missed their target.
Mama Mia women's network editor-in-chief Jamila Rizvi in discussion with Bob Katter. Photo: Screenshot, The Verdict, Nine Network 
And this was annoying, because Katter's actual argument was incredibly easy to (ahem) shoot down: the Good Guy With A Gun Stops Bad Guy With A Gun argument, which literally never works in the real world. Indeed, in the wake of the Northern Arizona University shooting earlier this month armed students on campus told media they didn't intervene, not least because they accurately figured that waving a gun around was a great way to be shot by police. That, of course, didn't stop Katter from raging that "My reaction [to Port Arthur] was rage and fury – wasn't there anyone there to help these people? Wasn't there anyone there to deal with this piece of scum?"
That language is important, since the most illuminating thing that came across was just how unsuccessful Mental Health Week has been in educating people in how to talk about mental health in the media. Both Katter and Latham railed against dangerous "nutcases" and "lunatics", showing the same nuanced understanding of the subject as Brown, who jumped in apropos of nothing to call for firing squads "…where we'll line up all the pedophiles". Sorry, what?
With time ticking down the argument burnt out quickly enough as the subject turned to the addictiveness of pokies and whether they needed to be regulated.
Again, everyone pretty much agreed something should be done, although the solutions ranged from gambling limits (Rae) and education (Mollard) to Latham's demand that clubs to identify problem gamblers and then somehow magically force them to get help, and Brown's helpful and insightful declaration that gamblers have only themselves to blame, because "I'm sick of their victim mentality. No-one puts a gun to their head." Seriously, Brown? What were you talking about mere minutes ago?
Rizvi gently added out that pokies are targeting an older demographic and that the bigger problem down the road is the increasing popularity of online gambling: a point eloquently made 90 seconds later during a commercial for the Crownbet app.
Maybe it was the topics, or maybe it was the mix of panellists, but on tonight's evidence The Verdict needs either a whole lot of loose cannons spouting furious nonsense, which would be entertaining but pointless; or thoughtful experts who know what they're talking about, which would be interesting but also essentially make them Q&A. 
The danger is that The Verdict are replacing car crash television with something even worse: boring television.
“If I had my way, Port Arthur never would’ve occurred.” - @RealBobKatter #TheVerdict https://t.co/SkZ1K1NDgz
